quizzes.title: Mathematics Fundamentals - Algebra
quizzes.description: Test your understanding of basic algebraic concepts including equations, inequalities, and expressions.
quizzes.instructions: Read each question carefully. You have 30 minutes to complete this quiz. Each question is worth 10 points. Good luck!

questions.question: What is the value of x in the equation 2x + 5 = 15?
questions.explanation: Subtract 5 from both sides: 2x = 10, then divide by 2: x = 5

feedback.positive: Great job! You correctly solved the linear equation.
feedback.negative: Remember to isolate the variable by performing inverse operations on both sides.

feedback.positive: Excellent! You correctly applied the distributive property.
feedback.negative: Don't forget to distribute the 3 to both terms inside the parentheses.

questions.question: If y = 2x - 3, what is y when x = 4?

feedback.positive: Perfect! You correctly substituted and evaluated the expression.
feedback.negative: Remember to substitute the value of x and then perform the operations in order.

questions.question: The expression (a + b)² is equal to a² + 2ab + b²
questions.explanation: This is the expansion of (a + b)² using the binomial theorem.

feedback.positive: Correct! This is the standard expansion of a binomial squared.
feedback.negative: This is actually true. The formula (a + b)² = a² + 2ab + b² is a fundamental algebraic identity.

feedback.positive: Well done! You correctly solved the equation by isolating x.
feedback.negative: Try moving all terms with x to one side and constants to the other, then solve.

questions.question: What is the coefficient of x in the expression 7x² - 3x + 5?
questions.explanation: The coefficient of x is -3, which is the number multiplying the x term.

feedback.positive: Correct! The coefficient is the number directly multiplying the variable.
feedback.negative: The coefficient is the number that multiplies the variable. Look for the number before x (not x²).

questions.question: If 3x + 2y = 14 and x = 2, what is the value of y?

feedback.positive: Excellent work! You correctly substituted and solved for y.
feedback.negative: Substitute the value of x first, then solve the resulting equation for y.

questions.question: The inequality x > 5 means x is greater than 5
questions.explanation: The symbol > means 'greater than', so x > 5 means x is greater than 5.

feedback.positive: Correct! The > symbol means greater than.
feedback.negative: The > symbol means 'greater than', so this statement is true.

questions.question: Factor completely: x² - 9
questions.explanation: This is a difference of squares: x² - 9 = x² - 3² = (x + 3)(x - 3)

feedback.positive: Perfect! You recognized this as a difference of squares.
feedback.negative: This is a difference of squares pattern: a² - b² = (a + b)(a - b).

questions.question: What is the solution to the equation 2x + 10 = 0?

feedback.positive: Great! You correctly solved the equation.
feedback.negative: Subtract 10 from both sides, then divide by 2 to find x.

quizzes.title: English Language - Grammar and Vocabulary
quizzes.description: Assess your knowledge of English grammar rules, sentence structure, and vocabulary usage.
quizzes.instructions: This quiz covers grammar, vocabulary, and sentence structure. Read each question carefully. Time limit: 45 minutes.

questions.question: Choose the correct form: 'Neither the students nor the teacher _____ present.'
questions.explanation: With 'neither...nor', the verb agrees with the subject closest to it. 'Teacher' is singular, so 'was' is correct.

feedback.positive: Excellent! You correctly applied the subject-verb agreement rule for 'neither...nor'.
feedback.negative: With 'neither...nor', the verb should agree with the subject closest to it. Since 'teacher' is singular, use 'was'.

questions.question: The word 'ubiquitous' means present everywhere.
questions.explanation: Ubiquitous means existing or being everywhere at the same time.

feedback.positive: Correct! 'Ubiquitous' means present or appearing everywhere.
feedback.negative: Actually, 'ubiquitous' does mean present everywhere. It's a common vocabulary word.

questions.question: Identify the type of sentence: 'Although it was raining, we went to the park.'
questions.explanation: This is a complex sentence because it contains one independent clause and one dependent clause (starting with 'Although').

feedback.positive: Well done! You correctly identified this as a complex sentence.
feedback.negative: A complex sentence has one independent clause and at least one dependent clause. The 'Although' clause is dependent.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'I have been _____ for three hours.'
questions.explanation: The present perfect continuous tense requires the -ing form of the verb.

feedback.positive: Perfect! You correctly used the present perfect continuous tense.
feedback.negative: With 'have been', you need the present participle (-ing form) of the verb.

questions.question: Which sentence is grammatically correct?
options: Me and John went to the store.
John and I went to the store.
John and me went to the store.
I and John went to the store.
questions.explanation: When the pronoun is part of the subject, use 'I' (not 'me'). 'John and I' is the correct form.

feedback.positive: Correct! When pronouns are subjects, use 'I' instead of 'me'.
feedback.negative: When the pronoun is the subject of the sentence, use 'I' (not 'me'). Also, it's polite to mention others first.

quizzes.title: Physics - Motion and Forces
quizzes.description: Test your understanding of motion, velocity, acceleration, and Newton's laws of motion.
quizzes.instructions: This is a comprehensive midterm exam. You have 60 minutes. Show all work mentally. Each question is worth 10 points.

questions.question: What is the SI unit of force?
questions.explanation: Force is measured in Newtons (N), named after Sir Isaac Newton.

feedback.positive: Correct! Force is measured in Newtons.
feedback.negative: Force is measured in Newtons (N), named after the famous physicist.

questions.question: According to Newton's first law, an object at rest will remain at rest unless acted upon by an external force.
questions.explanation: Newton's first law states that objects at rest stay at rest, and objects in motion stay in motion, unless acted upon by an unbalanced force.

feedback.positive: Excellent! You understand Newton's first law of motion.
feedback.negative: This is true. Newton's first law describes inertia - objects resist changes in their motion.

questions.question: If a car accelerates from 0 to 60 m/s in 10 seconds, what is its acceleration?
questions.explanation: Acceleration = (final velocity - initial velocity) / time = (60 - 0) / 10 = 6 m/s²

feedback.positive: Perfect! You correctly calculated acceleration using a = Δv/Δt.
feedback.negative: Use the formula: acceleration = (final velocity - initial velocity) / time. Don't forget the units (m/s²).
